slides.title: TODAY'S MISSION
slides.subtitle: Unlocking the Superconsumer Code
slides.notes: Set the context. Explain that we are not reading every word today. We are training specific muscles.

slides.title: THE SPEED OF CONSUMPTION
slides.content:
• What is the 'cost' of getting products so fast?
  • How do you feel watching this speed?
  • Do you buy things online?
slides.notes: Play the video (Amazon Fulfillment Center). Elicit reactions to the sheer scale and speed. Is it impressive or scary?

slides.context_sentence: Companies must work fast to meet consumer demand.
slides.notes: Concept Check: Is a demand a polite request? (No). Is it strong? (Yes).

slides.context_sentence: Walmart is a huge multinational company.
slides.notes: Break it down: Multi (many) + National (countries). Ask for examples (Nike, Apple, etc.).

slides.context_sentence: Advertisements try to influence what you buy.
slides.notes: Ask: Who influences you? Friends? TikTok? Parents?

slides.context_sentence: Gen Y expects brands to interact with them on social media.
slides.notes: Action: Show interaction. Talking, texting, replying.

slides.context_sentence: Netflix uses data to personalize your movie list.
slides.notes: Ask: Examples of personalized things? (Phone cases, coffee orders, algorithms).

slides.title: STRATEGY: SKIMMING
slides.content:
• üöÄ Don't read every word.
  • üëÄ Look at the first sentence of each paragraph.
  • üîç Look for repeated keywords.
  • üí° Example: If you see '1980', 'born', 'young' -> It's about AGE.
  • ‚è±Ô∏è You have 6 minutes.
slides.notes: Explain Skimming. It is fast. It is for the 'Gist' (Main Idea). Do not get stuck on difficult words.

slides.title: TASK 2: MATCHING HEADINGS
checklist_items: A. Reading the future of shopping?
C. Why is Gen Y hard to influence?
D. Are large stores still growing?
E. How fast is online shopping growing?
slides.notes: Start Timer. Monitor students. The options are randomized. Warn them!

slides.title: TASK 2: ANSWERS (1/5)
slides.explanation: The text defines the demographic, mentioning birth years (late 70s to mid 90s) and distinguishing them from their parents.
slides.snippet: We are the Generation Y... born between the late 1970s and the mid 1990s.
slides.notes: Elicit answer. Ask: 'How did you know?' (Keywords: 'born' -> Who is Gen Y).

slides.title: TASK 2: ANSWERS (2/5)
slides.answer: D. Are large stores still growing?
slides.explanation: The paragraph discusses the physical size and number of malls, mentioning 'expansion' and 'largest in the world'.
slides.snippet: This is the age of the expansion of shopping centers... Dubai Mall, the largest in the world...
slides.notes: Evidence = Expansion.

slides.title: TASK 2: ANSWERS (3/5)
slides.answer: E. How fast is online shopping growing?
slides.explanation: It focuses on the massive increase in internet spending figures over 15 years.
slides.snippet: The growth of internet shopping... spending rose from ¬£800 million to ¬£60bn.
slides.notes: Evidence = Numbers growing.

slides.title: TASK 2: ANSWERS (4/5)
slides.answer: C. Why is Gen Y hard to influence?
slides.explanation: It explains that traditional ads don't work because this generation prefers peer reviews and blogs.
slides.snippet: We do not pay attention to advertising... we rely on blogs and reviews.
slides.notes: Evidence = Not paying attention.

slides.title: TASK 2: ANSWERS (5/5)
slides.answer: A. What is the future of shopping?
slides.explanation: The text predicts how brands must behave to survive, focusing on interaction and relationships.
slides.snippet: Brands will have to interact with us... make us feel we have a personal relationship.
slides.notes: Evidence = Interaction / Relationship.

slides.title: STRATEGY: SCANNING
slides.content:
• üî¢ Look for the shape of numbers.
  • üí∑ Look for symbols (¬£, $, %).
  • üí° Example: If asked about 'Money', scan for '¬£' or '$'.
  • üõë Stop when you find the number.
  • üìñ Read the sentence around it.
slides.notes: Explain Scanning. Like a search engine. Do not read the story. Just find the data.

slides.title: TASK 3: FIND THE DATA
slides.content:
1. A million square meters
  2. 750,000
  3. 15 and 28
  1. ¬£800 million / ¬£114 billion
  2. one in three
slides.notes: Start Timer. Students must write what the number represents.

slides.title: TASK 3: ANSWERS (1/5)
slides.explanation: The physical area of the Dubai Mall.
slides.snippet: ...Dubai Mall... covers an area of over a million square meters.
slides.notes: Check answers.

slides.title: TASK 3: ANSWERS (2/5)
slides.explanation: The number of weekly visitors to the Dubai Mall.
slides.notes: Check answers.

slides.title: TASK 3: ANSWERS (3/5)
slides.explanation: The number of countries Walmart operated in, comparing 2011 to 2015.
slides.snippet: ...Walmart... operated in 15 countries... by 2015, this had risen to 28.
slides.notes: Check answers.

slides.title: TASK 3: ANSWERS (4/5)
slides.explanation: The substantial growth of online sales in the UK over a 15-year period.
slides.snippet: In the UK, spending rose from ¬£800 million in 2000 to ¬£60bn in 2015.
slides.notes: Check answers.

slides.title: TASK 3: ANSWERS (5/5)
slides.explanation: The ratio of Gen Y shoppers who consult blogs before purchasing.
slides.snippet: One in three of us says we rely on blogs and reviews... before we splash out.
slides.notes: Check answers.

slides.title: STRATEGY: DETAILED READING
slides.content:
• üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Read carefully.
  • ‚öñÔ∏è True: The text says this 100%.
    (Text: 'John loves apples' -> Q: 'John likes fruit' = TRUE)
  • ‚ùå False: The text says the opposite.
    (Text: 'John hates apples' -> Q: 'John loves apples' = FALSE)
  • ‚ùì Not Given: The text does not say.
    (Text: 'John eats apples' -> Q: 'John loves apples' = NG. Maybe he eats them but hates them?)
slides.notes: Explain T/F/NG with the Apple examples. Emphasize that 'Not Given' means the information is missing, not just wrong.

slides.title: TASK 4: T / F / NG
checklist_items: 4. Amazon's inventory compared to sports fields.
slides.notes: Start Timer. Remind them to underline the proof in the text.

slides.title: TASK 4: ANSWERS (1/5)
slides.explanation: The text explicitly states that malls are NOT dead; they are evolving into entertainment hubs.
slides.snippet: Some people think the mall is dead, but they are wrong... becoming hubs of entertainment.
slides.notes: Check Q1.

slides.title: TASK 4: ANSWERS (2/5)
slides.explanation: The text says Gen Y habits are similar everywhere, not different.
slides.snippet: ...and we have remarkably similar habits across the globe.
slides.notes: Check Q2.

slides.title: TASK 4: ANSWERS (3/5)
slides.explanation: The text refers to personal relationships as something the *parents'* generation had, not the current one.
slides.snippet: Our parents' generation had a personal relationship with the people they bought from.
slides.notes: Check Q3.

slides.title: TASK 4: ANSWERS (4/5)
slides.explanation: The comparison matches the text exactly.
slides.snippet: Amazon's warehouse... is the size of ten soccer fields.
slides.notes: Check Q4.

slides.title: TASK 4: ANSWERS (5/5)
slides.explanation: The text states that transparency and interaction are expectations of this generation.
slides.snippet: We expect transparency and interaction from the brands we buy from.
slides.notes: Check Q5.

slides.title: YOUR CONSUMER PROFILE
slides.content:
Write a reflection (70+ words):


  • Do you trust 'Influencers' and blogs?
  • Do you prefer Personalized ads or do you find them creepy?
  • What was the last thing you bought because of social media?
slides.notes: Writing Task. 10 Minutes. Monitor and assist with vocabulary.
